div1.ab: The General Consul of France in New York to Mr. Minister of Foreign Affairs.
div1.p: It exists at No 690 of 8th Avenue, in New York, a protestant society that, under the name of "International Missionary Alliance," works on evangelizing the new regions open to civilization. Since 7 years ago when it was founded, it has arrived at creating around 60 missions of which the majority are found in Africa and in Asia; it counts 300 missionnaries and, last year, it was able to spend for its work a half-million francs.
I received, last week, the visit of Mr. Rev. Henry Wilson, Doctor

of theology, president of the Committee of the Missions of this Association. In returning to me the report, that Your Excellence will find enclosed, the work of the organization since its foundation, Mr. Wilson called my attention to the extension that the Society is proposing to give to the establishments that it created in the English Colony of Sierra-Leone, along the river Rokel: eager to cross the eastern borders of this colony, it would dream to establish a mission in Farina, on the Niger, in French Sudan.

But ignoring if the regulations oppose its installation in our possessions. Mr. Dr Wilson prays that I indicate to him which formalities the International Alliance would have to fill to obtain the permission to evangelize this region.
In the ignorance where I am myself of all special regulations on this subject, I can

only signal to you, Mister Minister, the demand that Mr. Wilson submitted to me in praying Your Excellence to inform me of such response that Mr. Minister of the Colonies would believe to need to give.

I see by the budget of the association, that a sum of more than 40,000 francs was, last year, spent by it in Brittanic Sudan and I do not doubt that all effort is attempted to respond to the christian civilization among the barbaric tribes of West Africa do not merit being encouraged. Nevertheless, since I have been in the United States, I had the occasion to follow the work of the majority of the american missionaries and I must say that in the politcal point of view, their action did not always to the protection of all criticism. These are those who brought the revolution of the Hawaian Islands and attempted to annex these islands into their country Aux Iles Carolines, they created

diffuculties in the Spanish government, in Anatolia and in Armenia, they around them ideas of independence that contributed for many to the unfortunate event of last Autumn. Furthermore Dr. Wilson left me that the work of the Alliance would not have been without encountering some opposition in Sierra-Leone on the part of english rival missions, and it is my point that our agent in Free Town could elucidate.

If the civil collaboration of the International Alliance could be accepted in our possessions, this should only be on the conditions such as this concourse never fuit to become a cause of difficulty for us and even less cause of financial reclamations the day where we become to deny ourselves of these services./.
